THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Pennsylvania National Mutual Casualty Insurance Company,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Larry Corley, Anna Corley, Robbie Pearson and Audrey Pearson, d/b/a Pearsonâ€™s 
        Funeral Home, Warren Robinson and State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance 
        Company,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-438
Heard June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed August 4, 
  2004

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
F. Barron Grier, III, and Joseph Henry, both of Columbia, for Appellant. 
E. Dale Lang, Jr., James B. Lybrand, Jr., Paul T. Collins, and Larry Cornell 
  Smith, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Pennsylvania National Mutual Casualty 
  Insurance Company sought a declaratory judgment that policy exclusions absolved 
  it of the duty to provide a defense for or indemnify Pearsonâ€™s Funeral Home 
  for injuries sustained by Pearsonâ€™s employee.Â  The circuit court held policy 
  exclusions did not apply.Â  We dismiss Pennsylvania Nationalâ€™s appeal as moot.
FACTS
Larry Corley was injured in a collision involving 
  a hearse and another limousine while chauffeuring for Pearsonâ€™s.Â  Pearsonâ€™s 
  insured all three vehicles under a commercial automobile insurance policy issued 
  by Pennsylvania National.Â  
Corley and his wife brought an action against Pearsonâ€™s 
  and Warren Robinson, the other limousine driver, alleging negligence and loss 
  of consortium.Â  Pennsylvania National denied liability coverage.Â  Before Pennsylvania 
  Nationalâ€™s denial of benefits could be adjudicated, the Corleysâ€™ suit was removed 
  from the active roster.Â  The Corleys later refiled their suit specifically seeking 
  recovery under the uninsured motorist provisions of Pearsonâ€™s policy.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Before the Corleysâ€™ suit was restored to the active roster, 
  Pennsylvania National brought a declaratory judgment action arguing policy exclusions 
  disallowed both liability and uninsured motorist coverage and, consequently, 
  it had no duty to defend or indemnify the funeral home in the Corleysâ€™ underlying 
  tort suit. Â Pennsylvania National added State Farm, the Corleysâ€™ automobile 
  insurer, as a defendant in an amended complaint, but requested no specific relief 
  from the insurer.Â  Following a hearing, the circuit court determined policy 
  exclusions were inapplicable.Â  Pennsylvania National appealed.
While the appeal was pending, Pennsylvania National entered 
  into a written agreement and release with the Corleys settling their tort claim 
  for $50,000.Â  The agreement released all parties from liability for injuries 
  arising from the automobile accident, and Pennsylvania National purported to 
  reserve the right to seek recovery against State Farm for the sum paid to the 
  Corleys.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A declaratory judgment action to determine insurance coverage 
  is an action at law.Â  Pennell v. Foster, 338 S.C. 9, 14, 524 S.E.2d 630, 
  633 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In an action at law, the appellate court may only correct 
  errors of law and will uphold the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings if any evidence 
  supports them.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 
  81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Pennsylvania National contends the trial court erred in determining 
  the exclusions of liability and uninsured motorist coverage did not apply to 
  the Corleysâ€™ claims.Â  We dismiss Pennsylvania Nationalâ€™s appeal as moot.
Pennsylvania National claims it reserved its claims denying 
  coverage and retained a subrogation right against State Farm by including the 
  following clause in the agreement it entered into with the Corleys:

Further, the undersigned in settling this action acknowledge 
  that the named plaintiff Larry Corley will no longer have an interest in the 
  declaratory judgment action currently on appeal but that Pennsylvania National 
  Mutual Casualty Insurance Company will maintain its rights to assert that it 
  is not the provider of coverage and will seek repayment of the amounts paid 
  in settlement from State Farm Insurance Company.Â  Nothing in this Release is 
  intended nor should be interpreted as barring that claim. 

Pennsylvania National reasons if this court accepts the reservation 
  clause as valid and determines the circuit court erred in finding the policy 
  exclusions inapplicable, it would then be able to seek reimbursement of the 
  settlement money from State Farm pursuant to State Farmâ€™s uninsured coverage 
  policy on the Corleys.Â  
Pennsylvania Nationalâ€™s amended complaint merely added State 
  Farm as a defendant in its declaratory judgment action.Â  The complaint demanded 
  no relief from State Farm and failed to provide any additional facts that would 
  support a finding State Farm was primarily or secondarily liable for Corleyâ€™s 
  injuries.Â  Therefore, the extent of State Farmâ€™s liability was never presented 
  to the circuit court for its determination and may not be addressed by this 
  court for the first time on appeal.Â  United Student Aid Funds, Inc. v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 356 S.C. 266, 273, 588 S.E.2d 
  599, 602 (2003) (An issue neither raised to nor ruled upon by trial court is 
  unpreserved for appellate review.); Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 152, 
  543 S.E.2d 224, 227 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œ[O]rdinarily a party may not receive relief 
  not contemplated in his pleadings.â€); Cf. Rushing v. Intex Prods., 
  Inc., 285 S.C. 595, 599, 330 S.E.2d 555, 557 (Ct. App. 1985) (In a declaratory 
  judgment action, the court may grant affirmative relief not requested if party 
  has pleaded facts upon which such relief may be granted.).Â  
The only issue Pennsylvania National presented for 
  determination in its pleadings was whether it was liable for the Corleysâ€™ injuries 
  under the liability and uninsured motorist coverage provisions of its own policy.Â  
  Pennsylvania National settled the question of its own liability when it voluntarily 
  settled with the Corleys and had the Corleys relieve all concerned parties from 
  liability.Â  As a result, there is no remaining claim upon which this court may 
  grant effective relief.Â  When some event occurs making it impossible for the 
  reviewing court to grant effective relief, the case is moot and may be properly 
  dismissed.Â  Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 567-68, 549 S.E.2d 591, 596 
  (2001) (holding a case becomes moot when some event occurs making it impossible 
  for the reviewing court to grant effective relief); Byrd v. Irmo High Sch., 
  321 S.C. 426, 430, 468 S.E.2d 861, 864 (1996) (holding the appellate courts 
  will not pass on moot or academic questions or make an adjudication where there 
  remains no actual controversy).
APPEAL DISMISSED.
 HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, 
  J., and WILLIAMS, A.J., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Gary W. Bennett,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


 Appeal From Horry County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge 


Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-439
Heard June 10, 2004 â€“ Filed August 13, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for 
  Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelanka 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General William E. Salter, III, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  Gary Wayne Bennett 
  appeals his convictions for armed robbery and murder in connection with the 
  death of Eva Marie Martin, arguing the trial court erred in limiting his cross-examination 
  of the Stateâ€™s key witness, Andrew Lindsay, on Lindsayâ€™s prior conviction for 
  second-degree murder.Â  Bennett argues he should have been able to impeach Lindsay 
  by revealing the specific nature of Lindsayâ€™s prior murder conviction, rather 
  than being limited to a general characterization of the conviction as an unspecified 
  felony.Â  We agree, but find the error harmless and affirm.
FACTS
Martin was discovered murdered in her home on May 
  23, 2000.Â  Earlier that month, Bennett and Lindsay had plotted to rob a Horry 
  County Taco Bell restaurant managed by Martin.Â  Martin was an acquaintance and 
  a coworker of Bennettâ€™s common-law wife.Â  Although Bennett and Lindsay obtained 
  a key to the restaurant, they were unable to open its safe because they did 
  not have the safeâ€™s combination 
Approximately two months later, police questioned 
  Lindsay regarding Martinâ€™s murder. [1] Â  Lindsay initially provided police at least two statements 
  denying knowledge of or involvement in Martinâ€™s murder.Â  He later recanted his 
  statement, admitted involvement in Martinâ€™s murder, but implicated Bennett as 
  the murderer.Â  Lindsay was later charged with Martinâ€™s murder, but entered a 
  plea bargain with the State.Â  Pursuant to the agreement, Lindsay pled guilty 
  to being an accessory after the fact, in exchange for which he would testify 
  that Bennett killed Martin.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Bennett was subsequently charged with and tried 
  for murder and armed robbery in connection with Martinâ€™s death.Â  The State moved 
  in imine to limit Bennettâ€™s impeachment of Lindsay by prohibiting testimony 
  regarding Lindsayâ€™s 1991 second-degree murder conviction from Illinois.Â  Conversely, 
  Bennett wanted to impeach Lindsay on cross-examination by revealing the fact 
  that he had previously been convicted of murder.Â  It is unchallenged that Lindsayâ€™s 
  murder conviction falls squarely within the admissibility parameters of Rule 
  609, SCRE. [2] Â  Rule 609(a)(1), 
  SCRE, provides in relevant part that impeachment of a non-defendant witnessâ€™s 
  credibility with evidence of the non-defendant witnessâ€™s past criminal convictions 
  is permissible â€œif the crime was punishable by death or imprisonment in excess 
  of one year under the law under which the witness was convictedâ€ and if under 
  Rule 403, SCRE, the court determines that the evidenceâ€™s probative value is 
  not â€œsubstantially outweighedâ€ by the danger of unfair prejudice. Here, the 
  trial judge indicated his intent to limit Bennett â€œto making inquiries without 
  identifying [Lindsayâ€™s 1991 second-degree murder conviction] as a second-degree 
  murder chargeâ€ ostensibly out of concern that testimony regarding the specific 
  nature of Lindsayâ€™s second-degree murder conviction would prejudice Bennett.Â  
  We are unable to discern from the record the rule of evidence or legal principle 
  relied upon by the trial judge in countermanding defense counselâ€™s intended 
  strategic use of relevant and admissible evidence.Â  In this regard, Bennettâ€™s 
  counsel insisted that he, not the court, assess potential prejudice arising 
  from the use of relevant and admissible evidence.Â  Bennettâ€™s stated strategy 
  was to confront and impeach Lindsay with every available weapon, including Lindsayâ€™s 
  murder conviction.Â  The trial judge, nevertheless, persisted with the limitation 
  on Bennettâ€™s desired impeachment of Lindsay.
Bennett later vigorously cross-examined Lindsay 
  regarding, among other things, the details of his plea bargain, the fact that 
  he lied to police in two sworn statements before admitting involvement in Martinâ€™s 
  murder, the fact that police found the Taco Bellâ€™s safe combination on a piece 
  of paper in Lindsayâ€™s wallet at the time of his arrest, and the fact that he 
  was currently serving a ten-year prison sentence for seven counts of second-degree 
  burglary, to which he pled guilty in 2001.Â  Regarding Lindsayâ€™s 1991 murder 
  conviction, Bennett asked â€œYouâ€™re a convicted felon, received a sentence of 
  fifteen years â€¦ to a charge that has nothing to do with the burglary charges 
  youâ€™re serving your time for now, isnâ€™t that right?â€Â  Lindsay replied, â€œYes.â€
In closing arguments, Bennett focused on the impact 
  of these issues on Lindsayâ€™s credibility, ultimately building a case implicating 
  Lindsay as Martinâ€™s murderer.Â  Among other things, he suggested Lindsay more 
  likely the perpetrator because while Bennett and his wife were close friends 
  with Martin, Lindsay was a mere social acquaintance less likely to care about 
  Martinâ€™s welfare.Â  He further noted that Lindsay, not Bennett, was found in 
  possession of the safeâ€™s combination, and that Lindsayâ€™s plea bargain with the 
  State motivated him to falsely implicate Bennett as the murderer. 
The trial judge instructed the jury regarding witness 
  credibility and impeachment, noting that its consideration of a witnessâ€™s criminal 
  record was limited to its assessment of the witnessâ€™s credibility.Â  Bennett 
  was subsequently convicted for murder and armed robbery.Â  Because he had previously 
  been convicted of first-degree burglary, Bennett was sentenced to concurrent 
  life terms without parole under the recidivist statute. 
  [3] Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
As a general rule, a trial courtâ€™s ruling on the 
  proper scope of cross-examination will not be disturbed absent a manifest abuse 
  of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  State v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. 
  189, 196, 498 S.E.2d 642, 645 (1998);Â  State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 
  621, 582 S.E.2d 426, 429 (2003).Â  This rule is subject to the Sixth Amendmentâ€™s 
  guarantee of a defendantâ€™s right to a â€œmeaningfulâ€ cross-examination of a witness.Â  
  State v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. at 196, 498 S.E.2d at 645.
DISCUSSION
Bennett argues the trial court improperly 
  limited his cross-examination of Lindsay regarding Lindsayâ€™s past conviction 
  for second-degree murder. [4]  According to Bennett, he should 
  have been able to confront and impeach Lindsay with the murder conviction, rather 
  than the court-imposed restriction on Lindsayâ€™s cross-examination.Â  We agree, 
  but find the error harmless.Â  As noted, Rule 609 permits impeachment of a non-defendant 
  witness with the witnessâ€™s criminal conviction â€œif the crime was punishable 
  by â€¦ imprisonment in excess of one year.â€Â  This rule comports with the Sixth 
  Amendment to the United States Constitutionâ€™s â€œConfrontation Clause,â€ through 
  which a defendant has the right to cross-examine a witness concerning bias or 
  partiality.Â  State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 331, 563 S.E.2d 315, 319 
  (2002).Â  On cross-examination, any fact may be elicited which tends to show 
  the witnessâ€™s interest, bias, or partiality.Â  Id.Â  â€œBefore a trial judge 
  may limit a criminal defendantâ€™s right to engage in cross-examination to show 
  bias on the part of the witness, the record must clearly show the cross-examination 
  is inappropriate.â€Â  Id.Â  In this case, Lindsay was a â€œwitnessâ€ previously 
  convicted of a crime, second-degree murder, which resulted in a sentence of 
  fifteen years.Â  Thus, we find that the trial judge properly concluded that the 
  evidence of Lindsayâ€™s murder conviction was admissible under Rule 609(a)(1) 
  of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence.Â Â  
Here, the trial judgeâ€™s basis for finding the cross-examination 
  â€œinappropriateâ€ arose from his concern regarding the potential prejudice to 
  Bennett, who advocated admitting the evidence.Â  The court expressed concern 
  that a jury might determine Bennett had committed the murder because Lindsay, 
  his friend and co-defendant, had a previous murder conviction.Â  We find this 
  rationale not only erroneous, but also an unwarranted intrusion into strategy 
  determinations vested solely in the accused and his counsel. 
â€œThe authority to decide the objectives and means 
  of litigation is divided between the client and the attorney.â€Â  Alex Sanders 
  & John S. Nichols, Trial Handbook for South Carolina Lawyers Â§ 1:4, 
  23 (2d ed. 2002); see Rule 407, SCAR, Rules of Prof. Conduct, 1.2(a) 
  (a lawyer shall abide by a clientâ€™s decisions concerning the objectives of representation 
  and shall consult with the client as to the means by which they are to be pursued);Â  
  cf. Whitehead v. State, 308 S.C. 119, 122, 417 S.E.2d 529, 531 
  (1992) (Stating that in the context of post-conviction relief that â€œ[c]ourts 
  must be wary of second-guessing counselâ€™s trial tactics; and where counsel articulates 
  a valid reason for employing certain strategy, such conduct will not be deemed 
  ineffective assistance of counsel.â€).Â  â€œSubject to a few exceptions, the client 
  makes all decisions regarding the objectives of litigation and representation.â€Â  
  Sanders & Nichols, Trial Handbook for South Carolina Lawyers, Â§ 1:4 
  at 23.Â  However, â€œ[t]he lawyer generally decides the means to be used to achieve 
  the clientâ€™s legitimate objectives, especially legal and tactical questions.â€Â  
  Id. at 24.Â  Where, as here, proposed evidence is relevant and admissible, 
  and its use is merely a function of defense strategy involving the weighing 
  of potential benefits and risks of prejudice, the decision of the defendant 
  and his counsel controls.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s decision here directly contravened 
  the strategic tactics of Bennettâ€™s counsel and had the effect of limiting Bennettâ€™s 
  confrontation and impeachment of Lindsay.Â  We find this an improper limitation 
  of Bennettâ€™s right to confront a witness, amounting to legal error.
However, an improper 
  limitation of the defendantâ€™s right to confront a witness is not per se 
  reversible if the error was â€œharmless beyond a reasonable doubt.â€Â  State 
  v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 333, 563 S.E.2d at 318.Â  An error is harmless beyond 
  a reasonable doubt where, in view of the entire record, the error did not contribute 
  to the verdict beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  See Id., 349 at 334, 
  563 S.E.2d at 319.Â  While we recognize the importance of Lindsayâ€™s testimony 
  to the Stateâ€™s case, we are persuaded that the error is harmless in light of 
  the overwhelming level of impeachment otherwise permitted during Bennettâ€™s cross-examination 
  of Lindsay, including the details of his plea bargain, the fact that he was 
  in prison for multiple counts of burglary, and the fact that he had lied to 
  police in multiple statements before admitting his involvement in the crime.Â  
  We further note that some impeachment value was derived from the reference to 
  the Lindsayâ€™s murder conviction as a â€œfelonyâ€ for which he received a â€œfifteen 
  year sentence.â€Â  Moreover, Bennett was allowed to argue, without objection, 
  the issue of Lindsayâ€™s third-party guilt during his closing argument.Â  In light 
  of the totality of these circumstances, we find the error harmless beyond a 
  reasonable doubt.Â  This conclusion is consistent with decisions in other jurisdictions.Â  
  Where a trial court errs in limiting a defendantâ€™s ability on cross-examination 
  to confront and impeach a witness, such error is generally harmless when the 
  cross-examiner is allowed to otherwise pursue a thorough and meaningful cross-examination.Â  
  See Artis v. U.S., 505 A.2d 52 (D.C.App. 1986) (In a prosecution 
  for burglary and larceny it was error to curtail appropriate line of cross-examination 
  of prosecution witness concerning juvenile charges pending against him, but 
  such error was harmless where cross-examination otherwise highlighted witnessâ€™s 
  motives to curry favor with the government to escape prosecution for burglaries 
  and other offenses and to avoid possible revocation of his probation);Â  Morris 
  v. State, 166 Ga.App. 137, 303 S.E.2d 492 (1983) (Error occurred in burglary 
  prosecution where defendant was precluded from cross-examining accomplice who 
  testified for prosecution regarding existence of any pending charges and promises 
  of immunity, but error was harmless where defendant was able to question defendant 
  regarding his motives through another line of questioning);Â  State v. Long, 
  372 N.E.2d 804 (Ohio, 1978) (Where examination of record in homicide prosecution 
  disclosed that defense counsel aggressively cross-examined eyewitness to homicide 
  and that such examination, among other things, elicited witness's admission 
  that at time of trial he was incarcerated and had been convicted of receiving 
  stolen property, even if trial court erred in not allowing cross-examination 
  of such witness as to whether he had pending motion for shock probation, no 
  material prejudice was demonstrated by record and any error was harmless beyond 
  reasonable doubt); see generally, R.P. Davis, Annotation, Preventing 
  or Limiting Cross-Examination Of Prosecutionâ€™s Witness As To His Motive For 
  Testifying, 62 A.L.R.2d 610 (1958 & 2004 Supp.).Â  Accordingly, Bennettâ€™s 
  convictions are
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  In the interim, Lindsay and his wife moved from South Carolina.

 
   [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We are not confronted 
    with that portion of Rule 609, SCRE, dealing with use of a prior conviction 
    against an accused.Â  Rule 609, SCRE, and related case law provide for considerations 
    unique to the accused.Â  See Green v. State, 338 S.C. 428, 433-34, 
    527 S.E2d. 98, 101 (2000) (Declining to hold past convictions of the accused 
    inadmissible in all cases, but instead finding that a trial court should weigh 
    the probative value of the prior convictions against their prejudicial effect 
    to the accused and determine, in its discretion, whether to admit the evidence.Â  
    In doing so, the factors a trial court should consider are (1) the impeachment 
    value of the prior crime; (2) the point in time of the conviction and the 
    witnessâ€™ subsequent history; (3) the similarity between the past crime and 
    the charged crime; and (5) the centrality of the credibility issue.).Â  The 
    Green factors are not implicated by the testimony of a witness who 
    is not the accused, such as Lindsay.

 
   [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  South Carolinaâ€™s recidivist 
    statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§17-25-45 (Supp. 2000), mandates, among other things, 
    an automatic life without parole sentence when a person has been convicted 
    of more than one â€œmost seriousâ€ offense.Â  Such â€œmost seriousâ€ offenses, as 
    defined by the statute, include first-degree burglary, murder, and armed robbery.Â  
    Here, the State notified Bennett and his counsel that because Bennett had 
    a prior first-degree burglary conviction, he would be subject to a sentence 
    of life in prison without parole if convicted on either the murder or armed 
    robbery charge.

 
   [4]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Bennett objected to the 
    courtâ€™s limitation of his cross-examination of Lindsay in the in limine 
    hearing, but he did not renew his objection when Lindsay testified.Â  Generally, 
    an in limine ruling does not preserve an issue for review because a 
    motion in limine is not a final determination.Â  State v. Forrester, 
    343 S.C. 637, 642, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001).Â  An issue ruled upon in an 
    in limine hearing is therefore not preserved for appellate review unless 
    the moving party makes a contemporaneous objection when the evidence is introduced, 
    except where the judgeâ€™s ruling is, in effect, a final ruling.Â  Id.Â  
    Here, due to the circumstances surrounding the trial judgeâ€™s ruling in the 
    present case, the State conceded at oral argument that the issue is preserved 
    for review.Â  We accept the Stateâ€™s stipulation and address the issue on its 
    merits.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Harmon James Weldon,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Tiger Town RV and Marine Center, Inc., Tracker Marine, LP, and Brunswick 
        Corporation, Inc.,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-354
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  3, 2004
Withdrawn, Substituted, and Refiled, 
  August 18, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
REMANDED IN PART 


  
    
      
Rivers Lawton McIntosh, of Anderson, for Appellant.
Charles E. Carpenter, S. Elizabeth Brosnan, Leslie A. Cotter, 
  Jr., all of Columbia; and Christopher G. Olson and C. Nicholas Lavery, both 
  of Clemson; and Peter G. Siachos, of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this consumer litigation 
  action over the purchase of a boat, Harmon Weldon appeals the trial courtâ€™s 
  grant of summary judgment to Tiger Town RV and Marine Center, Inc., Tracker 
  Marine, L.P., and Brunswick Corporation, Inc. on claims for breach of warranty 
  and revocation of acceptance.Â  We affirm in part and reverse and remand in part.Â  

FACTS
On February 28, 2001, Weldon purchased 
  a 2000 Procraft 190 SuperPro boat with a 175 horsepower Mercury engine from 
  Tiger Town RV and Marine Center.Â  Weldon signed the contract and made a down 
  payment of $2,500.00 that day.Â  He returned the following day to retrieve the 
  boat.Â  At that time, he was given an In Service Checklist and a Brunswick Outboard 
  Operation, Maintenance & Warranty Manual.Â  In the manual, Brunswick limited 
  its obligation under the warranty to repairing a defective part, or at its option, 
  refunding the purchase price or replacing the part. It also disclaimed the implied 
  warranties of merchantability and fitness and excluded all incidental and consequential 
  damages.Â  Weldon asserted he never received a manual or warranty booklet from 
  Tracker Marine.Â  However, he acknowledges that if such a warranty is in effect, 
  it is the same as that provided by Brunswick.Â Â  
 Weldon has experienced numerous problems 
  with the boat.Â  Even before he picked it up, the boat had a blown fuse.Â  On 
  March 2, 2001, before Weldon had even put the boat in the water, he discovered 
  a fuel leak.Â  The boat also needed work on the live well and ignition at this 
  time.Â  On March 8, Weldon again had problems related to the motor.Â  The engine 
  would cut off when engaging the trim and the trim gauge did not work properly.Â  
  The boat would also lose power and fail to accelerate.Â  Tiger Town placed a 
  call to Brunswick regarding a blown fuse and voltage regulator problem during 
  this service visit.Â  Around March 14, 2001, Weldon brought the boat back to 
  Tiger Town after experiencing problems with the boatâ€™s alarm system sounding 
  when the boat hit waves.Â  There was also a problem with the storage compartment 
  lid.Â  Around April 21, 2001, Weldon again had problems with the boat losing 
  power and had difficulty starting it.Â  The cranking battery died and the boat 
  would not plane off.Â Â  Through May and June of 2001, Weldon continued to have 
  problems with the boat planning off, the tilt/trim gauge, the starting battery, 
  and the trolling motor.Â  He also had a problem with the boatâ€™s fabric cover 
  and compartment covers.Â Â  Weldon again returned the boat to Tiger Town with 
  an enumerated list of problems and instructions to keep the boat until all the 
  problems were fixed.Â  The boat stayed at Tiger Town for six to seven weeks.Â  
  When Weldon discovered that all of the problems had not been addressed, his 
  attorney delivered a letter to Tiger Town dated August 15, 2001, explaining 
  that Weldon revoked his acceptance of the boat.Â  Around this same time, Weldon 
  took the boat to test it on the lake, but it would not start.Â  
On October 24, 2001, Weldon brought suit 
  alleging causes of action for breach of warranty and revocation of acceptance 
  against Brunswick, Tracker, and Tiger Town.Â  Subsequent to Weldon bringing this 
  action, another wiring problem with the boat was discovered and repaired.Â  After 
  this repair, Tim Marlowe, a Technical Account Manager for Brunswick, inspected 
  the boat and took the boat out on the water.Â  He stated in his affidavit that 
  there was no nonconformity or defect regarding the motor.Â  However, he acknowledged 
  Weldon had alleged that the tilt/trim gauge on the boatâ€™s console was not properly 
  calibrated.Â Â Â  
Tiger Town, Brunswick, and Tracker moved 
  for summary judgment. Â The trial court granted the motions of Brunswick and 
  Tracker as to all causes of action.Â  The court also granted Tiger Townâ€™s motion 
  on the revocation of acceptance claim.Â  However, it denied Tiger Townâ€™s motion 
  on the breach of warranty claim, determining an issue of fact existed as to 
  whether certain oral statements were permissible puffing or created an express 
  warranty.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
To obtain summary judgment, the moving 
  party must demonstrate there is â€œno genuine issue of material fact and the moving 
  party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€ Wilson v. Moseley, 
  327 S.C. 144, 146, 488 S.E.2d 862, 863 (1997).Â  In deciding a motion for summary 
  judgment, the court must view the evidence and the inferences that can be drawn 
  therefrom in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. Id. â€œSummary 
  judgment should not be granted even when there is no dispute as to the evidentiary 
  facts, if there is a dispute as to the conclusions to be drawn therefrom.â€Â  
  Laurens Emergency Med. Specialists, P.A. v. M.S. Bailey & Sons Bankers, 
  355 S.C. 104, 108-09, 584 S.E.2d 375, 377 (2003). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Revocation of Acceptance
Weldon argues the trial court erred in 
  granting summary judgment to all defendants on the revocation of acceptance 
  cause of action.Â  We agree in part.Â  
The South Carolina Uniform Commercial 
  Code (UCC) sets forth theÂ  elements for revocation of acceptance as follows:

(1)Â  The buyer may revoke his acceptance of a lot or commercial 
  unit whose nonconformity substantially impairs its value to him if he has accepted 
  it 
  
(a)Â  on the reasonable assumption that its nonconformity would 
  be cured and it has not been seasonably cured; or 
(b)Â  without discovery of such nonconformity if his acceptance 
  was reasonably induced either by the difficulty of discovery before acceptance 
  or by the sellerâ€™s assurances. 
  
(2)Â  Revocation of acceptance must occur within a reasonable 
  time after the buyer discovers or should have discovered the ground for it and 
  before any substantial change in condition of the goods which is not caused 
  by their own defects. It is not effective until the buyer notifies the seller 
  of it. 
(3)Â  A buyer who so revokes has the same rights and duties 
  with regard to the goods involved as if he had rejected them.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-608 (2003).
As a ground for granting Brunswick and 
  Tracker Marine summary judgment on Weldonâ€™s claim for revocation, the trial 
  court held, â€œBecause Brunswick and Tracker did not sell the boat to [Weldon], 
  [Weldon] can neither reject nor revoke acceptance of the goods as to these parties.â€Â  
  Weldon failed to specifically appeal this holding.Â  Accordingly, it is the law 
  of the case. Â See ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & 
  Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 472 (1997) (stating an unappealed 
  ruling is law of the case).Â  We must therefore affirm the trial courtâ€™s grant 
  of summary judgment on this issue as to Brunswick and Tracker Marine. 
As to Weldonâ€™s claim for revocation against 
  Tiger Town, we hold the trial court erred in granting summary judgment.Â  
In granting Tiger Townâ€™s motion, the trial 
  court stated that Weldonâ€™s continued use of the boat operated as an acceptance 
  and that his revocation was not timely made.Â  This was error. 
In Mockabee v. Wakefield Buick, Inc., 
  298 S.C. 386, 380 S.E.2d 848 (Ct. App. 1989), a case cited by the trial court, 
  this court ruled a car buyerâ€™s attempted revocation almost 22 months after the 
  date of purchase was not timely made.Â  However, the court cautioned that â€œ[t]wenty-two 
  months is not per se untimely in all situations.â€ Id. at. 388, 
  380 S.E.2d at 849.Â  The court in Mockabee noted there was some evidence 
  the buyer brought the car to the dealership shortly after purchase for an oil 
  leak and starting problem and then brought it back three or four times sometime 
  during the first year of ownership to complain about problems unspecified in 
  the record, but there was no evidence he returned it to the dealership in the 
  ten months preceding his attempted revocation. Id.Â  Furthermore, the 
  buyer never took the car to the service department but took it to the used car 
  salesman instead.Â  The court found the evidence failed to establish the dealership 
  made reasonable assurances to the buyer the carâ€™s defects would be cured thus 
  delaying the buyerâ€™s decision to revoke his acceptance.Â  Id.Â  Instead 
  it showed the buyer ignored the problems.Â  Id. Thus, the court concluded 
  that based on this evidence and considering the time lapse before notice of 
  revocation was given, the only reasonable inference to be drawn from the evidence 
  is that the attempted revocation was not timely given in accordance with Section 
  36-2-608(2).Â  Mockabee, 298 S.C. 388-89, 380 S.E.2d at 849.
Unlike the situation in Mockabee, throughout 
  the less than six months between his purchase of the boat and his letter notifying 
  Tiger Town that he was revoking his acceptance of it, Weldon continually delivered 
  the boat to Tiger Town for repairs.Â  According to Weldon, every time he tried 
  to put the boat in the water, a new problem developed and he has not even used 
  a full tank of gas in the boat yet.Â  The only evidence of a change in condition 
  of the boat is that it has a few scratches on the hull.Â  We hold a jury could 
  find Weldon revoked his acceptance within a reasonable time after he discovered 
  or should have discovered the ground for it and before any substantial change 
  in condition of the boat that was not caused by its own defects. 
The trial court also found as a matter 
  of law Weldon did not effectively revoke acceptance because he continued to 
  exert an ownership interest over the boat.Â  We disagree with this finding.Â  

When Weldon left the boat at Tiger Town 
  for several weeks during the summer of 2001, Tiger Town threatened to charge 
  him rent for storing the boat if he did not collect it.Â  In his letter revoking 
  acceptance dated August 15, 2001, Weldon notified Tiger that he would maintain 
  possession of the boat pending a full refund.Â  There is no evidence in the record 
  Weldon continued to use the boat except for testing it for additional problems.Â  
  Accordingly, we find a jury could reasonably conclude Weldon had effectively 
  tendered the boat to Tiger Town.Â  
We furthermore find Weldon presented evidence 
  sufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact as to whether the alleged 
  nonconformity of the boat substantially impaired its value to Weldon.Â  Whether 
  the goods have a nonconformity that substantially impairs the value of the goods 
  to the buyer is a subjective test.Â  Herring v. Home Depot, 350 S.C. 373, 
  380, 565 S.E.2d 773, 776 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In addition, this is a question of 
  law rather than of fact.Â  Burris v. Lake Wylie Marina, Inc., 285 S.C. 
  614, 615, 330 S.E.2d 559, 560 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  As listed above, Weldon has 
  experienced numerous problems with the boat.Â  He stated in an affidavit, â€œThe 
  repetitive nature of the electrical problems makes me [wary] about whether or 
  not these problems have been or could be fixed.Â  The unrepaired problems and 
  the multiple continuing problems substantially impair the value of the boat 
  to me.â€Â Â  We find a jury issue exists as to whether Weldon has met the subjective 
  test to support a cause of action for revocation of acceptance.Â  
Accordingly, we hold the trial court erred in granting 
  Tiger Town summary judgment on Weldonâ€™s claim for revocation of acceptance.Â  

Breach of Warranty
Weldon contends the trial court erred 
  in granting the summary judgment motions of Brunswick and Tracker as to the 
  breach of warranty claims.Â  We agree.Â  
Under the UCC, the parties to a contract for the 
  sale of goods may establish exclusive, limited written warranties and limitation 
  of damages as a remedy for breach thereof.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-719 (2003).Â  
  The agreement may limit the buyerâ€™s remedies to repair or replacement of nonconforming 
  goods or parts, and if such remedy is expressly agreed to be exclusive, it is 
  the sole remedy.Â  Id.Â  In addition, the agreement may limit or exclude 
  consequential damages unless the limitation or exclusion is unconscionable.Â  
  Id.Â  
Weldon contends there are genuine issues of material 
  fact as to whether Brunswick and Tracker created limited warranties.Â  We agree.Â  

â€œAccording to the prevailing interpretation of 
  the Uniform Commercial Code, a disclaimer printed on a label or other document 
  and given to the buyer at the time of delivery of the goods is ineffective if 
  a bargain has already arisen.â€Â  Gold Kist, Inc. v. Citizens & Southern 
  Natâ€™l Bank of S.C., 286 S.C. 272, 277, 333 S.E.2d 67, 70 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  
  However, a disclaimer made after the closing of the sale can be made a binding 
  part of the contract if the parties agree to the modification.Â  Id. atÂ  
  277-78, 333 S.E.2d at 71.Â  In order to support an agreement to modify, the evidence 
  must reveal that the buyer acquired knowledge of the offered modification and 
  had an opportunity to object to it.Â  Id. at 278,Â  333 S.E.2d at 71.
Although Weldon signed the bill of sale on February 
  28, 2001, he was not given Brunswickâ€™s warranty manual until he picked up the 
  boat the next day.Â  Weldon asserts he never received any warranty information 
  from Tracker.Â  In Brunswickâ€™s manual, the limited warranty, disclaimer of implied 
  warranties, and exclusion of consequential damages appear on page nine, with 
  additional information on pages eight, fourteen, and fifteen.Â  Weldon asserted 
  in his affidavit, â€œThe warranty was not pointed out to me or discussed with 
  me, and it was not until I subsequently looked through these materials that 
  I discovered the limited warranty.â€Â  Weldon did return the boat to Tiger Town 
  numerous times for repairs, which were made under Brunswickâ€™s and Trackerâ€™s 
  warranties.Â  However, a jury could reasonably find that Weldon never agreed 
  to be limited to the exclusive remedy of repairing a replacement part.Â  
Furthermore, even if the limited warranties 
  of both Brunswick and Tracker are in effect, a genuine issue of material fact 
  exists as to whether Weldon may still be entitled to the general remedies provided 
  in the UCC.Â  â€œWhere circumstances cause an exclusive or limited remedy to fail 
  of its essential purpose, remedy may be had as provided in this act."Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-719(2) (2003).Â  The official comments to this section 
  explain, â€œ[W]here an apparently fair and reasonable clause because of circumstances 
  fails in its purpose or operates to deprive either party of the substantial 
  value of the bargain, it must give way to the general remedy provisions of this 
  Article.â€
â€œWhere a seller is given a reasonable 
  chance to correct defects and the equipment still fails to function properly, 
  the buyer is deprived of the benefits of the limited remedy, and it therefore 
  fails of its essential purpose.â€Â  Bishop Logging Co. v. John Deere Indus. 
  Equip. Co., 317 S.C. 520, 533, 455 S.E.2d 183, 191 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  A jury 
  may justifiably find that the warranty operated to deprive the purchaser of 
  the substantial value of the bargain where the seller was unable to remedy numerous 
  major and minor defects within a reasonable time.Â  Id. at 533-34, 455 
  S.E.2d at 191 (citing Riley v. Ford Motor Co., 442 F.2d 670 (5th Cir. 
  1971)).Â  Similarly, the cumulative effect of numerous defects may substantially 
  impair the value of the goods to the buyer; thus, the limited warranty fails 
  of its essential purpose.Â  Id. at 534, 455 S.E.2d at 191 (citing Murray 
  v. Holiday Rambler, Inc., 265 N.W.2d 513 (1978)). 
Brunswick and Tracker assert that they have repaired 
  every defect in the boat pursuant to the warranties.Â  However, the evidence 
  demonstrates that as each repair was made, other defects appeared.Â  Even after 
  Weldon brought this action, a problem with the wiring harness was discovered.Â  
  Furthermore, the tilt-trim gauge remains defective.Â  There is evidence in the 
  record that responsibility for this defect is shared by Brunswick and Tracker.Â  
  We hold a jury could reasonably find Brunswick and Tracker were unable to remedy 
  all of the defects in the boat within a reasonable time and that cumulative 
  effect of these numerous defects substantially impaired the value of the boat 
  to Weldon.Â  Thus, a genuine issue of material fact exists as to whether the 
  limited warranty has failed of its essential purpose.Â  
 Finally, Weldon asserts it was premature 
  for the trial court to grant summary judgment as to incidental and consequential 
  damages.Â  We agree.Â  
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-719(3) (2003), provides, 
  â€œConsequential damages may be limited or excluded unless the limitation or exclusion 
  is unconscionable.â€Â  In Bishop Logging, this court held the exclusion 
  of consequential damages must be interpreted in light of the premise of â€œcertainty 
  of repairâ€ which underlay the entire contract.Â  317 S.C at 536, 455 S.E.2d at 
  192.Â  It noted that while the parties obviously agreed to exclude consequential 
  damages in the event that the seller performed its obligation to repair or replace 
  defect, the buyer could reasonably have expected to recover consequential damages 
  when the defects were never adequately corrected and the limited remedy proved 
  ineffectual.Â  Id.Â  The court found â€œthe failure of the limited remedy 
  in this case materially altered the balance of risk set by the parties in the 
  agreement.â€Â  Id. at 536, 455 S.E.2d at 193.Â Â  Thus, this court concluded 
  the trial court was correct in allowing the full array of remedies provided 
  by the UCC, including recovery of consequential damages and incidental losses. 
  Id. at 536-37, 455 S.E.2d at 193.Â  
In the present case, we find the issue 
  of the validity of the limitation on damages should be remanded with the above 
  issues.Â  Depending on the findings of the jury in the above issues, the court 
  may find that the â€œcertainty of repairâ€ underlies the limited warranty agreement 
  and that the failure of the limited remedy has materially altered the balance 
  of risk set by the parties in the agreement, rendering the limitation unconscionable 
  and thus unenforceable pursuant to Section 36-2-719(3).
As we find genuine issues of material 
  fact exist as to whether the limited warranties were created, whether such warranties, 
  if in existence, have failed as to their essential purpose, and whether the 
  limitation of damages is unconscionable, we hold the trial court erred in granting 
  Brunswick and Tracker summary judgment on Weldonâ€™s claims for breach of warranty.Â  

Conclusion
The trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment 
  to Brunswick and Tracker on Weldonâ€™s cause of action for revocation is affirmed.Â  
  The grant of summary to Tiger Town on the revocation cause of action is reversed.Â  
  The trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Brunswick and Tracker on Weldonâ€™s 
  cause of action for breach of warranty is reversed.Â  The case is remanded to 
  the trial court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
 AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED AND REMANDED 
  IN PART.
 ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â

v.
 
   
     
      
        Joe Lewis Robinson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Hampton County
  Â Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-441
  Submitted July 7, 2004 â€“ Filed August 23, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED

 
   
     
      
        Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster,Â  Chief Deputy Attorney General

          all of Columbia; and Solicitor RandolphÂ  Murdaugh, III, of Hampton,

PER CURIAM:Â  Joe Lewis Robinson appeals 
  his conviction for armed robbery, arguing the trial court erred in allowing 
  the victim to identify him as the culprit.Â  Specifically, Robinson argues the 
  court erred by allowing the solicitor to elicit testimony from the victim that 
  the victim picked Robinson out of a photo-lineup two days after the robbery.Â  
  Pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), Robinsonâ€™s counsel 
  attached a petition to be relieved, stating he has reviewed the record and concluded 
  the appeal lacks merit.Â  Robinson filed a separate pro se brief 
  which we have considered.Â  After a thorough review of the record pursuant to 
  Anders and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), 
  we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.Â  
APPEAL DISMISSED. 
  [1]

title: Lindsey v. Vann
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA



THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        J. C. and Nancy Lindsey, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Eley and Lisa Vann and I. A. Romo, PLS, Defendants,
        Of whom Eley and Lisa Vann are, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
  Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-442
  Heard May 13, 2004 â€“ Filed August 23, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        Clarke W. McCants, III, of Aiken, for Appellants. 
        Eric K. Englebardt, of Greenville, for Respondents. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  J. C. and Nancy Lindsey brought actions for negligence, 
  trespass, and conversion against their next-door neighbors, Eley and Lisa Vann, 
  alleging the Vanns improperly erected a fence on their property. 
  [1] Â  The master in equity determined the original boundary between the 
  two properties placed the fence on the Vannsâ€™ side of the line, but modified 
  the line in favor of the Lindseys based on a finding of acquiescence by the 
  Vannsâ€™ predecessors in title.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS 
The Lindseys and Vanns are adjoining property owners in a residential subdivision.Â  
  Both properties front a cul-de-sac with the common boundary running from an 
  undisputed northern terminus at the joint rear corner southward to the edge 
  of the cul-de-sac.Â  The location of the southern terminus of the boundaryâ€”the 
  point on the cul-de-sacâ€”is the point in dispute.Â  
 The Vanns constructed a fence along a line southward from the undisputed northern 
  terminus to a point on the cul-de-sac that the Lindseys contend is within their 
  property line.Â  When the Lindseys brought their action, the Vanns counterclaimed 
  for declaratory judgment to determine the true boundary between the properties.Â  
  At trial, the Vannsâ€™ surveyor testified he discovered an older pin buried at 
  a different point on the cul-de-sac that he believed was the true southern terminus. 
  [2] Â  The Lindseysâ€™ surveyor claimed the southern terminus was at another 
  point, 21.34 feet west of the Vannsâ€™ fence, thereby placing the fence well within 
  the Lindseysâ€™ property.Â  On cross-examination, the Lindseysâ€™ surveyor admitted 
  he did not find any artificial marker similar to the buried pin discovered by 
  the Vannsâ€™ surveyor to support his suggested location of the southern terminus.Â  

The master determined and held the true southern terminus of the boundary to 
  be as testified to by the Vannsâ€™ surveyor and as shown as pin 1 on the Vannsâ€™ 
  Exhibit No. 2.Â  The master therefore concluded the original and lawful boundary 
  was the line from the undisputed northern terminus to pin 1 on the cul-de-sac, 
  resulting in a finding that the fence is located on the Vannsâ€™ property.Â  However, 
  the master then concluded that the Vannsâ€™ predecessors in title had acquiesced 
  in the Lindseysâ€™ use of at least a portion of the disputed land.Â  Based on this 
  finding, the master ordered the boundary line be redrawn so that its southern 
  terminus is halfway between the points testified to by the two contending surveyors, 
  thereby giving each landowner one-half of the disputed property.Â  This division 
  required the Vanns to remove their fence.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW 
The Lindseysâ€™ complaint alleged the Vanns trespassed on their land and interfered 
  with their peaceable possession, but did not assert a claim of legal title.Â  
  Therefore, the Lindseysâ€™ cause of action is trespass quare clausum fregit.Â  
  Gunterâ€™s Island Hunting Club v. Hucks, 282 S.C. 124, 126, 317 S.E.2d 
  470, 472 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œAn action for â€˜trespass quare clausum fregitâ€™ may 
  be based upon possession only and not necessarily upon legal title.â€).Â  However, 
  the Vanns answered and counterclaimed for a declaratory judgment to determine 
  the true boundary between the properties.Â  The masterâ€™s order treated the partiesâ€™ 
  claims as a boundary dispute, and the Lindseys have not appealed the courtâ€™s 
  characterization or treatment of their action.Â  Accordingly, we review this 
  case as an equitable matter involving the location of a boundary.Â  Knox v. 
  Bogan, 322 S.C. 64, 67, 472 S.E.2d 43, 45 (Ct. App. 1996) (An action to 
  settle or fix a boundary may be treated as an equitable matter.); Uxbridge 
  Co. v. Poppenheim, 135 S.C. 26, 30-31, 133 S.E. 461, 462 (1926) (holding 
  when the plaintiff cannot prove with certainty where a boundary line is to show 
  the defendant has overstepped it, ordinary remedies at law are inadequate and 
  such a circumstance requires the interposition of equity).Â  
DISCUSSION
The Vanns contend the master erred by modifying the lawful boundary based on 
  a finding of acquiescence by their predecessors in title.Â  We agree. 
The master determined pin 
  1, unearthed by the Vannsâ€™ surveyor, was the accurate southern terminus of the 
  boundary and, as a result, the lawful boundary ran from pin 1 to the undisputed 
  northern terminus as shown on the Vannsâ€™ Exhibit No. 2.Â  This finding has not 
  been appealed and is, therefore, the law of the case.Â  Lucas v. Rawl Family 
  Ltd. Pâ€™ship, Op. No. 25817 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed May 3, 2004) (Shearouse 
  Adv. Sh. No. 18 at 36) (holding the trial judgeâ€™s unappealed ruling is the law 
  of the case).Â  
Accordingly, any variation or modification of the true boundary must be based 
  on proof of acquiescence by the parties.Â  The master found modification was 
  appropriate â€œto reflect the acquiescence of the Vannsâ€™ predecessor in title[.]â€Â  
  He cited the Lindseysâ€™ testimony they had maintained a portion of the disputed 
  area since 1977 without any objection from their then neighbors, the Alewines, 
  from whom the Vanns purchased their property in 1995. Â The master also 
  relied on the Lindseysâ€™ testimony that they planted grass and plants in the 
  area where the fence was constructed and Lisa Vannâ€™s testimony that she observed 
  the Lindseys mowing and tending the disputed area after they purchased the property 
  from the Alewines.Â  However, the court noted the Vanns testified they had also 
  performed work in the disputed area.Â  
To support a finding of acquiescence in this case, all parties, including the 
  Lindseys and the Vanns or the Vannsâ€™ predecessors in title, must have recognized 
  and accepted the modified boundary line as the true line.Â  See Knox, 
  322 S.C. at 71-73, 472 S.E.2d at 48-49 (holding adjoining property ownersâ€™ mutual 
  acquiescence in and recognition of a clearly defined boundary line for a long 
  period of time is proof of title by acquiescence); see also Klapman 
  v. Hook, 206 S.C. 51, 57, 32 S.E.2d 882, 884 (1945) (holding there is a 
  conclusive presumption that a certain line recognized and acquiesced in by adjoining 
  landowners for a sufficient length of time is the true boundary line).Â  However, 
  in this case, the parties have not recognized any clearly defined line and there 
  is no evidence in the record to support a finding they mutually recognized and 
  acquiesced in the modified boundary line created by the masterâ€™s final order.Â  
  The Lindseys testified at trial and conceded in their brief that they did not 
  know the location of the boundary.Â  The Alewines are deceased, and there is 
  no testimony that they recognized a clearly defined boundary either.Â  Contrary 
  to recognizing the modified boundary drawn by the master, the Vanns testified 
  they tended the disputed area and ultimately built the fence within the disputed 
  area.Â  Absent evidence of the partiesâ€™ acknowledgment of a clearly defined boundary, 
  there can be no acquiescence.Â  
Accordingly, we conclude modification of the lawful boundary line was error, 
  and the unappealed finding of the master establishing the boundary line running 
  from the undisputed northern terminus southward to the point on the cul-de-sac 
  identified as pin 1 on the Vannsâ€™ Exhibit No. 2 is the law of the case.Â  We 
  reverse so much of the masterâ€™s order as creates a new boundary and requires 
  the Vanns to dismantle their fence.Â  
REVERSED. 
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â 


 
   [1]  Â The Lindseys also sued 
    the Vannsâ€™ original surveyor, I. A. Romo.Â  Romoâ€™s dismissal has not been appealed.Â  
  

 
   [2]  Â The pin unearthed by 
    the Vannsâ€™ surveyor is marked as pin 1 on the Vannsâ€™ Exhibit No. 2.Â

          all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for 
          Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Douglas Francis King appeals 
  his conviction for three counts of desecration of human remains, one count of 
  obliteration, vandalization, or desecration of human burial grounds, one count 
  of malicious injury to personal property, and conspiracy.Â  King argues the trial 
  court erred by admitting evidence of uncharged prior bad acts that impermissibly 
  placed Kingâ€™s character in issue.Â  Kingâ€™s counsel attached to the brief a petition 
  to be relieved as counsel, stating that he had reviewed the record and concluded 
  this appeal lacks merit.Â  King did not file a separate pro se 
  brief.Â  After a thorough review of the record and counselâ€™s brief pursuant to 
  Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 
  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss [1]  Kingâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s 
  motion to be relieved.
APPEAL DISMISSED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â 


 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.
