title: Keowee Invest ment Group, LLC v. Pickens County
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED 
  ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Keowee Investment Group, LLC and the Cliffs at Keowee Vineyards Community 
          Association, Inc., Petitioners, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Pickens County, the South Carolina Department of Transportation, also 
          all other persons unknown claiming any right, title, interest in or 
          lien upon the real estate described herein as a portion of Cleo Chapman 
          Highway; unknown adults as being as a class designated as John Doe; 
          unknown infants, persons under disability or in a military service being 
          as a class designated as Richard Roe, Earnest W. Cooler, Jr., Dot Robertson 
          and Roger D. Gravely,
        Of Whom South Carolina Department of Transportation is, Respondent,
        and Dot Robertson, Roger D. Gravely and Will Gravely, (as a member 
          of the class of persons designated as John Doe or Richard Roe) are, 
          Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
  Â Joseph J. Watson , Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-459
  Heard May 13, 2004 â€“ Filed August 30, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        John S. Nichols, of Columbia; for Appellants.
        Beacham O. Brooker, Jr., of Columbia; David H. Wilkins, and Timothy 
          E. Madden, of Greenville; for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Keowee Investment Group, LLC 
  (Developer) and the Cliffs at Keowee Vineyards Community Association, Inc. (the 
  Association), commenced this action pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. section 57-9-10 
  (1991), seeking to close a highway that adjoined property in the Cliffs at Keowee 
  Vineyards subdivision.Â  The trial court found closing the road was in the best 
  interest of all concerned, determined the Developer and the Association should 
  have title to the road, and required access must remain open to all interested 
  in visiting McKinney Chapel.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Developer owned 1,200 acres of land in Pickens County that it developed into 
  the Cliffs at Keowee Vineyard subdivision.Â  The Association is an association 
  of the property owners within the subdivision, and it owns and maintains all 
  the roads and common areas within the subdivision.Â  The subdivision abuts a 
  portion of a public road known as Cleo Chapman Highway (the highway).Â  McKinney 
  Chapel and cemetery is at the end of the highway.Â  McKinney Chapel is at least 
  one hundred years old, and the historic church is maintained by Grace United 
  Methodist Church (Grace UMC).Â  Services are held at McKinney Chapel on a monthly 
  basis and for special events.Â Â Â  
Concerned about security, Developer and the Association 
  (collectively, Respondents) sought to close 14,000 feet of the highway that 
  is located within the boundaries of the subdivision.Â  They brought this action 
  to close the highway against Pickens County, the South Carolina Department of 
  Transportation, and a class of unknown persons who may claim some interest in 
  the highway, pursuant to section 57-9-10.Â  The private roads of the subdivision 
  connect to the highway within the portion they sought to close.Â  Several other 
  landowners, who owned property adjacent to the highway but were not within the 
  subdivision, also supported the privatization of the highway.Â  
Dot Robertson, Roger D. Gravely and Will Gravely 
  (collectively referred to as Appellants) intervened as members of the class 
  of persons designated as John Doe or Richard Roe in order to keep the highway 
  open to the public for access to the historic chapel and cemetery.Â Â  
Shortly after petitioning to close the highway, 
  Developer and Grace UMC reached an agreement regarding public access to the 
  chapel and cemetery if the highway were closed.Â  The agreement: granted Respondents 
  the right to construct a security gate to control access to the highway; granted 
  visitors and guests to the chapel and cemetery a nonexclusive perpetual easement 
  over the highway; and provided that Developer would maintain the chapel and 
  cemetery grounds.Â  The agreement also provided that visitors could access the 
  chapel and cemetery at any time and on any day by informing the guard at the 
  security gate of their destination; there would be no registration requirement.Â  

Just prior to the filing of the petition, Pickens County passed a resolution 
  calling for access to the chapel.Â  It provided:
 
  NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED THAT Pickens County is opposed to the gating 
    for private development of all state roads and of county arterial and collector 
    roads.Â  Where public roads are closed, provision must be made to allow public 
    access to significant cultural and natural resources that have traditionally 
    been provided to residents of Pickens County.
  BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that Pickens County requests that any access agreement 
    for Cleo Chapman Highway be irreversible and subject to periodic review to 
    assure that access provisions are maintained in good faith.Â  

Pickens County Res. No. 01-15.Â Â Â  
At trial, Respondents provided evidence of vandalism 
  and other crimes that have occurred along the portion of the highway they sought 
  to close.Â  They detailed the litter problems resulting from people traveling 
  the highway.Â  Respondents provided evidence of another development in which 
  they were successfully allowing access to an active church down a closed road 
  behind the developmentâ€™s security gate.Â  
Many of the other landowners who own property adjacent 
  to the closed portion of the highway testified regarding the impact on their 
  property.Â  Several echoed the sentiment that the gate would decrease vandalism, 
  crime, and litter.Â  They further testified that their property values would 
  be enhanced by the addition of the gate.Â  
Appellants appeared pro se at the 
  hearing.Â  They testified that closing the highway would unnecessarily restrict 
  access to the chapel.Â  They provided testimony from individuals who would feel 
  uneasy having to go through the gate in order to access the chapel.Â  Appellants 
  presented a petition signed by 4,000 individuals opposed to closing the highway 
  because it might inhibit public access to the chapel.Â  
The trial court recognized the importance of maintaining 
  public access to the chapel and cemetery.Â  The court found the agreement allowed 
  access to the chapel, did not unnecessarily restrict the movements of those 
  seeking to visit, and was not contrary to the Pickens County resolution.Â  The 
  agreement was incorporated into the final order such that if Respondents violated 
  the terms, it would be a violation of the order.Â  
In determining whether to close the highway, the 
  trial court considered the petition opposing the closing signed by 4,000 local 
  residents.Â  However, the court found the residents signing the petition were 
  not aware that they would be given permanent access to the chapel.Â  The court 
  also found the closing of the highway pursuant to the terms of the agreement 
  would be in the best interest of all concerned.Â  The court determined the security 
  of the area would be enhanced and the property owners in the area would not 
  be adversely affected.Â  Finally, the court found that title to the highway would 
  be vested in Respondents.Â  
Appellants filed a pro se post-trial petition for reconsideration.Â  
  The trial court held the petition was â€œfatally flawedâ€ because it was not served 
  upon the DOT and affirmed its prior findings on the merits.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The parties dispute whether a legal or equitable standard of review should 
  be applied.Â  Our supreme court has analyzed a trial courtâ€™s decision to close 
  a road pursuant to statute under an abuse of discretion standard.Â  First 
  Baptist Church of Mauldin v. City of Mauldin, 308 S.C. 226, 229, 417 S.E.2d 
  592, 594 (1992) (finding that in light of the evidence in the record supporting 
  the road closing, the trial court properly considered the publicâ€™s interest 
  as required by statute and no abuse of discretion occurred).Â  An abuse of discretion 
  occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled 
  by an error of law.Â  Ledford v. Pa. Life Ins. Co., 267 S.C. 671, 675, 
  230 S.E.2d 900, 902 (1976).Â  Accordingly, we will reverse the courtâ€™s decision 
  to close the highway only if the decision is unsupported by the evidence.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

 
I.Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction
Appellants argue the trial court erred in: (1) ruling that their post-trial 
  motion for reconsideration was fatally flawed because it was not served upon 
  the DOT; and (2) making this ruling sua sponte.Â  Respondents assert that 
  because Appellants failed to serve the DOT, their post-trial motion did not 
  toll the time period for filing their notice of appeal, and, thus, this court 
  does not have subject matter jurisdiction to entertain the appeal.Â  
In order to perfect an appeal to this court, a party must serve the notice 
  of appeal on all parties within thirty days of receipt of the written notice 
  of final order or judgment.Â  Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR.Â  When a party files a timely 
  post-trial motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict (j.n.o.v.) pursuant 
  to Rule 50(b), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rules 52 and 
  59, SCRCP, or for a new trial pursuant to Rule 59, SCRCP, the time period for 
  filing the notice of appeal is tolled until receipt of written notice of the 
  order granting or denying the post-trial motion.Â  Id.Â  The timely service 
  of the notice of appeal is a jurisdictional requirement, and the appellate courts 
  have no authority to â€œextend or expand the time in which the notice of appeal 
  must be served.â€Â  Mears v. Mears, 287 S.C. 168, 169, 337 S.E.2d 206, 
  207 (1985) (interpreting former Supreme Court Rule 1, Â§Â§ 1 A and 1 C).Â  The 
  failure to timely serve the notice of appeal â€œdivests this court of subject 
  matter jurisdiction and results in dismissal of the appeal.â€Â  Canal Ins. 
  Co. v. Caldwell, 338 S.C. 1, 5, 524 S.E.2d 416, 418 (Ct. App. 1999).
In the present case, Appellants intervened as defendants in Respondentsâ€™ suit 
  against Pickens County, the DOT, and other unknown persons claiming some right 
  or interest in the particular section of the highway they sought to close.Â  
  Although named as a defendant in the action, the DOT filed an answer expressing 
  that it had no objection to the closing of that section of the highway.Â  After 
  answering the complaint, the DOT notified Respondentsâ€™ counsel that it would 
  not appear at the hearing, and DOT did not appear further in the action.Â  Appellants 
  timely filed their pro se motion for reconsideration pursuant 
  to Rules 52(b) and 59(a) and (e), SCRCP.Â Â  However, Appellants failed to serve 
  their co-defendant, the DOT, with the motion. 
In ruling on the post-trial motion, the trial court 
  noted that Rule 5, SCRCP, requires that every written motion must be served 
  on all parties not in default.Â  Rule 5, SCRCP (â€œEvery . . . written motion . 
  . . shall be served upon each of the parties; but no service need be made on 
  parties in default for failure to appear. . . .â€).Â  The court found, sua 
  sponte, that Appellantsâ€™ failure to serve the DOT with the post-trial motion 
  pursuant to Rule 5 was a â€œfatal errorâ€ that rendered Appellantsâ€™ post-trial 
  motion untimely and of â€œno effect.â€Â  The court alternatively denied Appellantsâ€™ 
  post-trial motion on the merits.Â  Appellants filed their notice of appeal within 
  thirty days after receiving written notice of the order denying their motion 
  for reconsideration.Â Â  
Regardless of whether the trial court erred in ruling on this issue sua 
  sponte, we find the court erred in its interpretation of the effect of Rule 
  5, SCRCP.Â  Although Rule 5 does require service of motions on all parties to 
  an action, nothing in the rule indicates that failure to serve all parties is 
  a jurisdictional requirement, rendering the motion of â€œno effect,â€ or as if 
  it had never been filed.Â  The trial court still had jurisdiction to hear post-trial 
  motions timely filed in the case.Â  See Farmer v. Monsanto Corp., 
  353 S.C. 553, 557, 579 S.E.2d 325, 327 (2003) (â€œSubject matter jurisdiction 
  is the power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings 
  in question belong.â€) (citing Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 
  237-238, 442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994)); see also State v. Brown, 
  358 S.C. 382, 387, 596 S.E.2d 39, 41 (2004) (holding that where a defendant 
  failed to file his notice of appeal within ten days of his magistrate court 
  conviction, the failure to comply with the procedural requirements divested 
  the circuit court of appellate jurisdiction, not the subject matter jurisdiction 
  to hear and determine that class of appeal).Â  
Clearly, failure to serve a particular party with 
  a motion or order adverse to that partyâ€™s rights would render it ineffective 
  against that party.Â  See, e.g., Connor v. City of Forest Acres, 
  348 S.C. 454, 461-62, 560 S.E.2d 606, 609-10 (2002) (noting that service of 
  the notice of intent to appeal is a jurisdictional requirement, and the failure 
  to serve particular parties meant they were not part of the appeal); Universal 
  Benefits, Inc. v. McKinney, 349 S.C. 179, 183, 561 S.E.2d 659, 661 (Ct. 
  App. 2002) (noting that judgments should not be issued without notice to a party 
  whose rights are affected, the court stated that â€œa person against whom a judgment 
  or order is taken without notice may rightly ignore it and may assume that no 
  court will enforce itâ€ against him).Â  However, the rules do not indicate that 
  failure to serve one party renders the motion untimely or completely ineffective 
  against the other parties served.Â  
We see no prejudice where, as in the present case, 
  the party not served with a post-trial motion was disinterested in the action.Â  
  The DOT did not contest Respondentsâ€™ petition and did not appear at the hearing 
  to voice opposition to Appellantsâ€™ position.Â  Because the DOT was not interested 
  in asserting any rights in the matter, its substantial rights were not prejudiced 
  by the lack of its presence at the post-trial hearing. [1] Â  Brown v. Mickens, 256 S.C. 346, 348, 
  182 S.E.2d 417, 417-18 (1971) (â€œGenerally, a party interested in resisting 
  the relief sought by a motion has a right to notice sufficient to give him an 
  opportunity to be heard.â€) (emphasis added); see Nishitani v. Baker, 
  921 P.2d 1182, 1192-93 (Haw. Ct. App. 1996) (noting that although plaintiffs 
  violated Hawaii Rule of Civil Procedure Rule 5(a) by failing to serve the defendants 
  with notice of substitution, the court concluded that â€œsuch failure did not 
  affect Defendantsâ€™ substantial rights and was, thus, harmless errorâ€).Â  
Although Appellants violated Rule 5 by failing to serve 
  the DOT with notice of the post-trial motion, there is no evidence that the 
  DOTâ€™s substantial rights were prejudiced.Â  Thus, the motion was timely filed 
  and served upon the interested parties in the action.Â  Accordingly, the trial 
  court erred in finding the failure to serve the DOT rendered the post-trial 
  motion ineffective.Â  
We now turn to the question of whether Appellantsâ€™ appeal was timely.Â  Because 
  we have already determined that Appellantsâ€™ post-trial motion was timely, the 
  motion tolled the time period for filing their notice of appeal until after 
  receipt of the order denying the motion.Â  Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR.Â  Appellants 
  served their notice of appeal within thirty days of receipt of the order denying 
  the motion.Â  Accordingly, their notice of appeal was timely and this court has 
  jurisdiction to hear the appeal. 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Closing of the Highway
Appellants argue the trial court misconstrued the facts and erred in closing 
  the highway.Â  We find the trial court did not abuse its discretion because there 
  is sufficient evidence in the record to support the courtâ€™s decision.
Section 57-9-10 provides: â€œAny interested person, the State or any of its political 
  subdivisions or agencies may petition a court of competent jurisdiction to abandon 
  or close any street, road or highway whether opened or not.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 57-9-10 (1991).Â  The determination is controlled by a best interest standard: 
  â€œIf the court shall determine that it is to be the best interest of all concerned 
  that such street, road or highway be abandoned or closed, the court shall then 
  determine in whom the title thereto shall be vested and issue an appropriate 
  order.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-9-20 (1991).
 The South Carolina Supreme Court addressed the appropriate interest to be 
  considered in closing a road: 

  A public street may not be vacated for the sole purpose of benefiting an 
    abutting owner.Â  However, the mere fact that the vacation was at the instigation 
    of an individual who owns abutting property does not invalidate the vacation 
    or constitute abuse of discretion, nor does the fact that some private interest 
    may be served incidentally.Â  On the other hand, it must appear clearly that 
    no consideration other than that of public interest could have prompted the 
    action.Â Â  

First Baptist Church of Mauldin, 308 S.C. 
  at 229, 417 S.E.2d at 594 (citations omitted).
The reasons proposed by Respondents for closing the portion of the highway 
  included: safety of residents of the development and other landowners; a need 
  to decrease vandalism in the area; and a need to reduce other crimes occurring 
  along the highway.Â  Respondents also noted that McKinney Chapel would be protected 
  from vandalism by closing the highway.Â  
Several landowners and other individuals testified 
  regarding the vandalism of property along the highway.Â  Deputy Dewey Smith of 
  the Pickens County Sheriffâ€™s Department testified that the Sheriffâ€™s Department 
  would not be able to provide adequate security for the residents of the development 
  because of its location and distance from the Sheriffâ€™s Office. While many landowners 
  abutting the highway testified that their property values would increase after 
  the closing, they also explained one of the main reasons for closing the highway 
  would be to provide better security to landowners and the chapel.Â Â  
Jim Anthony, president of the Developer, testified 
  that reports of vandalism and other serious crimes had decreased as a result 
  of hiring security personnel, but he and landowners in the development sought 
  to close the highway to increase security.Â  Anthony admitted that closing the 
  highway and increasing security would increase the value of the property within 
  the development and along the closed portion of the highway.Â  Anthony also detailed 
  his experience in operating another gated road, which provided access to an 
  active church under an agreement with the church for ten years without a problem. 

Both Anthony and Joe Durham, Chairman of the Board 
  of Trustees of Grace UMC, testified regarding the agreement to allow access 
  to McKinney Chapel and cemetery.Â  Both believed the gate would increase security 
  for the chapel and help preserve it as a historical or tourist location. 
Several individuals with ties to the chapel or 
  cemetery expressed concerns that a gate would restrict access or intimidate 
  people wishing to visit McKinney Chapel or cemetery.Â  Thomas Watson testified 
  that he was followed to the chapel by a man in an unmarked car who observed 
  him for an extended period of time.Â  He feared that if the gate is erected and 
  visitors to the chapel are monitored, it would be very intimidating.Â  Finally, 
  Dot Robertson testified regarding the history of McKinney Chapel, expressed 
  concerns regarding the publicâ€™s access to the historical site, and presented 
  a statement from the Sierra Club expressing their concern over the possible 
  loss of public access to the church.Â  
Patrick Bryant presented the court with a petition 
  signed by 4,000 people in both Pickens and Oconee counties opposing the closing 
  of the highway.Â  It is not clear whether the individuals signing the petition 
  knew of the agreement between Developer and Grace UMC to provide access to McKinney 
  Chapel.Â  However, Bryant testified he still believed persons wanting to visit 
  the chapel through the gate would be prevented from doing so, notwithstanding 
  the agreement.Â  
It is clear that the trial court was concerned 
  about restricting access to the chapel.Â  However, we find, based upon the evidence 
  presented at trial, the court appropriately considered the benefits and detriments 
  to everyone involved.Â  The agreement between Developer and Grace UMC provides 
  substantial access to anyone wishing to visit the chapel or cemetery.Â  Although 
  the court expressed some concern regarding how the agreement would be enforced, 
  the agreement was ultimately incorporated in the court order so that any violation 
  of the agreement could be considered contempt of the court order and appropriate 
  sanctions would apply.Â Â  
Nevertheless, Appellants argue that the trial court 
  erred in finding the agreement did not violate the Pickens County resolution 
  because bringing a contempt action would be burdensome.Â  The evidence supports 
  the trial courtâ€™s finding that the agreement allows unfettered access, complies 
  with the resolution, and provides an appropriate remedy in the nature of a contempt 
  action.Â  
The evidence also supports a finding that security 
  in the development and at the chapel would be increased by closing the highway 
  and installing the security gate.Â  There was uncontested testimony that the 
  Developer had successfully operated a security gate in another development that 
  still allowed unfettered access for members of an existing church inside the 
  gate.Â  The trial court properly considered the interests of all persons concerned, 
  and more importantly the public at large, in rendering its decision.Â  
Finally, Appellants argue the trial court erred in discounting the petition 
  signed by 4,000 residents opposing the highway closing.Â  The trial court specifically 
  held that it believed the persons signing the petition were unaware they would 
  be given permanent access to the chapel.Â  It does appear that the petition was 
  circulated prior to execution of the agreement providing access between the 
  Developer and Grace UMC.Â  Thus, the trial court did not err in this finding.Â Â Â Â Â  

The trial court rendered its decision to close 
  the Highway after carefully considering the interests of the public.Â  Accordingly, 
  we find no abuse of discretion in the courtâ€™s decision to close the portion 
  of the highway at issue.
III.Â Â Â  Title to the Closed Highway
Appellants maintain the trial court erred in vesting title in Respondents once 
  it determined the highway should be closed.Â  We disagree.
First, Appellants lack standing to assert the trial 
  court improperly transferred title to Respondents.Â  Appellants contend the rightful 
  owner is the DOT.Â  However, Appellants have not asserted any right to the property 
  or claim title should have been vested in them.Â  â€œA party cannot appeal from 
  a decision which does not affect his or her interest, however erroneous and 
  prejudicial it may be to some other personâ€™s rights and interests.â€Â  Beaufort 
  Realty Co. v. Beaufort County, 346 S.C. 298, 301, 551 S.E.2d 588, 589-90 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  DOT, and not Appellants, would be the appropriate party to 
  appeal this determination.
Even if Appellants had standing to raise the issue, 
  the trial court properly transferred title to Respondents.Â  The road closing 
  statute provides that once a court determines that closing a road is in the 
  public interest, it may determine in whom title should be vested.Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 57-9-20 (1991).Â  The power to declare ownership of the closed road does 
  not grant the court the power to create or destroy a fee simple interest in 
  the property.Â  The court may only declare who owns legal title.Â  Hoogenboom 
  v. City of Beaufort, 315 S.C. 306, 318-19, 433 S.E.2d 875, 884 (Ct. App. 
  1992).Â  Further, â€œin the absence of some statutory disposition, abandonment 
  or vacation of a public street vests absolute possession and title in the abutting 
  property owners. . . .â€Â  City of Greenville v. Bozeman, 254 S.C. 306, 
  317-18, 175 S.E.2d 211, 216 (1970).Â Â  
In its answer, Pickens County stated that it had never owned or maintained 
  any portion of the highway.Â  DOT noted in its answer that the land which later 
  became the highway came within the state highway system in approximately 1940.Â  
  Appellants presented DOT documents at trial dating back to 1939.Â  The documents 
  all indicated that DOT had a right-of-way over the highway, not fee simple title.Â Â  

In its order, the trial court referred to DOT as the 
  â€œownerâ€ of the highway.Â  Nevertheless, after determining that closing the highway 
  would benefit the public, the court vested title in the highway to Respondents.Â  
  In their post-trial motion, Appellants alleged the trial court erred in vesting 
  ownership in Respondents after finding the DOT was title owner of the highway.Â  
  In the order denying the post-trial motion, the trial court clarified its prior 
  order stating that the evidence supported a finding that the DOT owned only 
  a right-of-way over the property, and thus, the title to the property was correctly 
  vested in the abutting landowners. 
The evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s determination.Â  Although the initial 
  order closing the highway mistakenly refers to DOT as the â€œowner,â€ all the evidence 
  supports the trial courtâ€™s subsequent order that the DOT owned only a right-of-way.Â  
  Therefore, title to the property upon closing the highway was correctly vested 
  in Respondents as abutting landowners.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court 
  did not abuse its discretion in transferring title in the closed portion of 
  the highway to Respondents.
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in closing a portion of 
  the highway.Â  The evidence in the record supports the finding that, while it 
  did benefit adjoining landowners, it would also be in the best interest of the 
  public.Â  Additionally, we hold the court properly transferred title in the closed 
  portion of the highway to Respondents.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial 
  court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


 
   
    [1]  Interestingly, the DOT has not filed a brief in this appeal to complain 
    about its lack of notice of the post-trial hearing.

title: State v. Meggs
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED 
  ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Jimmy Donald Meggs, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
  Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-460
  Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed August 31, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John 
          W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
          and Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
          Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Jimmy Donald Meggs, Jr., was 
  convicted of two counts of engaging a child for sexual performance and two counts 
  of contributing to the delinquency of a minor.Â  Meggs appeals, arguing the trial 
  court erred in: (1) allowing testimony regarding prior bad acts; and (2) excluding 
  evidence.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Meggs was the organizer and leader of a paintball league in Pamplico, South 
  Carolina.Â  In order to get the paintball league established, Meggs claimed he 
  was a captain in the National Guard and the league was associated with the military.Â  
  The organization was named the â€œVanguard Knights,â€ though it had no affiliation 
  with the actual organization by that name.Â  Meggs portrayed the league to parents 
  as a way to instill discipline in boys.Â  The boys were given paintball guns, 
  wore military fatigues, had ranks, were responsible for chores, and would participate 
  in military drills including marching.Â  According to several children, any child 
  not obeying orders was shot at close range with a paintball gun.Â  The paintball 
  games were held on weekends, and some of the participants would camp overnight 
  in tents in the field. 
The victims, nine-year-old twins A.B. and B.B. 
  [2] , participated in the league and spent several nights in the field.Â  
  Merline Buntin, an employee of the cafeteria where the victims attended school, 
  took A.B. and B.B. to school and church.Â  On one occasion, A.B. told her that 
  he was subjected to sexual misconduct.Â  Buntin informed the victimsâ€™ mother.Â  
  Meggs was subsequently arrested and charged with two counts of engaging a child 
  for sexual performance and two counts of contributing to the delinquency of 
  a minor. 
Prior to trial, the parties disagreed over whether the State could present 
  the testimony of four additional children.Â  The trial court held an in 
  camera hearing.Â  The defense objected to the testimony because it included 
  evidence of bad acts not substantially similar to the charges.Â  After hearing 
  the testimony, the court excluded two of the four boysâ€™ testimonies, but the 
  court determined the two other boys, D.C. and his brother E.C., could testify.Â  

During the trial, the State offered the testimonies of victims A.B. and B.B.Â  
  A.B. testified Meggs picked them up, and they would spend the whole weekend 
  in the field and camp overnight in tents.Â  Both boys testified that, at the 
  direction of Meggs, they were required to engage in oral sex with each other 
  and with at least one of the other boys in the paintball league.Â  Both A.B. 
  and B.B. described how Meggs forced them to simulate a sex act by having one 
  boy lie down and place a paintball on his genitals while the other boy would 
  be forced to retrieve the paintball with his mouth while doing push-ups over 
  the other boy.Â  A.B. and B.B. each separately testified that they would have 
  been shot with paintballs for refusing to do as Meggs instructed.Â  According 
  to both boys, Meggs would watch as they performed the acts he demanded, but 
  he would later tell them he had just been joking.Â  The boys denied that Meggs 
  was their motherâ€™s boyfriend and that he ever spent the night at their home.Â  
  Finally, both A.B. and B.B. testified they did not report the incident because 
  they were afraid of Meggs.Â Â  
Brothers D.C. and E.C. also testified regarding the incidents at the paintball 
  field.Â  Both testified that they witnessed Meggs force A.B. and B.B. to perform 
  oral sex and to simulate sex with push-ups.Â  D.C. and E.C. both testified that 
  Meggs also made them perform the sex simulation push-ups.Â  Both D.C. and E.C. 
  testified that they would be shot if they ever disobeyed an order from Meggs.Â  

 In addition to testifying about the acts Meggs forced D.C., E.C., and victims 
  A.B. and B.B. to perform, D.C. testified regarding an incident where Meggs attempted 
  to have oral sex with him when he spent one night alone in a tent with Meggs.Â Â Â  

A.B. and B.B.â€™s mother testified she was told of the alleged abuse by Buntin.Â  
  She testified she contacted law enforcement.Â  She stated she had several conversations 
  with her sons regarding the incidents, and they said it happened on the weekends 
  they were at the paintball field.Â  On cross-examination, the victimsâ€™ mother 
  testified Meggs never stayed overnight in her home, never bought groceries for 
  her, and never gave her money.Â  She testified she never asked him for money 
  and she was not in a relationship with Meggs. 
Meggs testified at trial, denying that he ever forced any of the boys to do 
  anything sexual or that he ever shot a child with a paintball at close range.Â  
  He admitted lying about his credentials.Â  Meggs sought to show that the victimsâ€™ 
  mother was motivated by money, testifying that he had a relationship with her 
  and gave her money.Â Â Â  
The jury found Meggs guilty on all counts.Â  He 
  was sentenced to two twenty-year terms of imprisonment on the charges of engaging 
  a child in sexual performance.Â  The second twenty-year sentence was suspended 
  with five years probation.Â  Meggs was also sentenced to imprisonment for three 
  years on each of the counts of contributing to the delinquency of a minor, to 
  be served concurrently with the first twenty-year sentence.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
 â€œThe admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of 
  the trial judge, whose decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse 
  of discretion.â€Â  State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 121, 551 S.E.2d 240, 244 
  (2001).Â  This court recently held that for purposes of admission of evidence 
  of prior crimes or misconduct to establish a common scheme or plan, the determination 
  of whether the facts surrounding the prior crime or misconduct evidence a common 
  scheme or plan is a question of law.Â  State v. Tutton, 354 S.C. 319, 
  326-27, 580 S.E.2d 186, 190 (Ct. App. 2003).

LAW/ANALYSIS

 
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Prior Bad Acts
Meggs contends the trial court erred by allowing a portion of D.C.â€™s testimony 
  into the record because it was unfairly prejudicial and should have been excluded 
  as a prior bad act under State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).Â  
  We disagree.
In addition to describing the acts Meggs forced victims A.B. and B.B. to perform 
  and the â€œpush-upsâ€ he ordered D.C. and E.C. to perform, D.C. testified during 
  his in camera testimony that when he was alone with Meggs one 
  night, Meggs unzipped his pants, asked him if he was scared, and inched his 
  head closer to D.C.â€™s genitals.Â  D.C. stated Meggs later asked him if he could 
  perform oral sex on him.Â  At the end of all the in camera testimony, 
  Meggs moved to exclude D.C.â€™s testimony, arguing that it did not meet the clear 
  and convincing standard in that it did not have a â€œclose similarityâ€ to the 
  other acts.Â  The trial court ruled D.C.â€™s testimony could be admitted at trial 
  because there was a logical connection between the charged offenses and the 
  acts described by D.C.Â  D.C. repeated his testimony regarding the tent incident 
  during the trial, without objection.Â Â Â  
This issue is not preserved for our review on appeal.Â  â€œGenerally, a motion 
  in limine seeks a pretrial evidentiary ruling to prevent the disclosure 
  of potentially prejudicial matter to the jury.â€Â  State v. Owens, 346 
  S.C. 637, 651, 552 S.E.2d 745, 752 (2001).Â  â€œA pretrial ruling on the admissibility 
  of evidence is preliminary and is subject to change based on developments at 
  trial.â€Â  Id. at 651, 552 S.E.2d at 752-53.Â  A ruling on a motion in 
  limine is usually not final and the losing party must renew his or her 
  objection when the evidence is presented.Â  State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 
  502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993); State v. Gagum, 328 S.C. 560, 564-65, 
  492 S.E.2d 822, 824 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œUnless an objection is made at the time 
  the evidence is offered and a final ruling made, the issue is not preserved 
  for review.â€Â  Schumpert, 312 S.C. at 507, 435 S.E.2d at 862.Â  However, 
  where the motion is ruled on immediately prior to the introduction of the evidence 
  in question and no other testimony is presented to provide a basis for the trial 
  court to change its ruling, the ruling is final and no further objection is 
  necessary.Â  State v. Tufts, 355 S.C. 493, 497, 585 S.E.2d 523, 525 (Ct. 
  App. 2003), cert. denied (June 24, 2004); Samples v. Mitchell, 
  329 S.C. 105, 109, 495 S.E.2d 213, 215 (Ct. App. 1997); State v. Mueller, 
  319 S.C. 266, 268-69, 460 S.E.2d 409, 410-11 (Ct. App. 1995).
Although Meggs objected to all of D.C.â€™s testimony 
  during the in camera hearing, he did not renew his objection during 
  D.C.â€™s trial testimony.Â  Five witnesses, including victims A.B. and B.B., testified 
  at trial prior to D.C., potentially providing a basis for Meggs to approach 
  the trial court again about excluding D.C.â€™s testimony.Â  As Meggs failed to 
  object during trial, the issue is not preserved for review on appeal.Â  Schumpert, 
  312 S.C. at 507, 435 S.E.2d at 862.
Further, even assuming the issue was preserved 
  and the evidence was improperly admitted, any error was harmless.Â  Whether an 
  error is harmless depends on the circumstances of the particular case.Â  In 
  re Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 62-63, 584 S.E.2d 893, 897 (2003).Â  â€œNo definite 
  rule of law governs this finding; rather, the materiality and prejudicial character 
  of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.â€Â  
  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985).Â  An 
  error is harmless where it could not have reasonably affected the result of 
  the trial.Â  Harvey, 355 S.C. at 63, 584 S.E.2d at 897.Â  Thus, an insubstantial 
  error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where guilt has been 
  conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion 
  can be reached.Â  State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 179, 460 S.E.2d 368, 
  371 (1995).
There was overwhelming evidence to conclusively 
  prove Meggsâ€™ guilt.Â  Eyewitnesses testified to the sexual acts directed by Meggs.Â  
  Other witnesses confirmed that the boys had described the various sexual acts.Â  
  Finally, Meggsâ€™ credibility was seriously called into question by his claim 
  of being a captain in the National Guard and the deceptive nature of the paintball 
  league.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court to allow D.C.â€™s testimony 
  is affirmed.

II.Â Â Â Â Â  Other Testimony
Meggs contends the trial court erred in refusing to allow his father to testify 
  regarding the content of two telephone conversations.Â  He also asserts the court 
  erred in refusing to allow him to testify to statements made by the victimsâ€™ 
  mother regarding her need for money.Â  We disagree, and find even if the statements 
  were improperly excluded, it was harmless error.
A.
Meggs argues the trial court erred in finding his fatherâ€™s testimony regarding 
  two telephone conversations was hearsay because they were offered to show a 
  relationship between Meggs and the victimsâ€™ mother.Â  
At trial, Meggsâ€™ father testified that on one occasion, he 
  answered a telephone call from the victimsâ€™ mother.Â  He stated that the victimsâ€™ 
  mother believed she was talking to Meggs.Â  The State raised hearsay objections 
  to the testimony regarding what the victimsâ€™ mother asked Meggsâ€™ father while 
  on the phone.Â  After sustaining the hearsay objections, the court held an in 
  camera hearing to determine the admissibility of the testimony.Â  
During the in camera hearing, Meggsâ€™ counsel argued the purpose 
  of the testimony regarding the telephone conversation was to show that the victimsâ€™ 
  mother called looking for Meggs.Â  The court allowed Meggs to proffer his fatherâ€™s 
  testimony.Â  Meggsâ€™ father testified the victimsâ€™ mother called for Meggs to 
  come over to her house.Â  He also testified regarding a second telephone conversation 
  in which he â€œpicked up the phone and they [the victimsâ€™ mother and Meggs] were 
  arguing.â€Â  Meggsâ€™ father testified the subject of that conversation was â€œ[a]bout 
  money.â€Â  The trial court again sustained the objection, finding that the testimony 
  regarding both telephone calls was hearsay and that no foundation was properly 
  laid for the testimony.Â  The court limited Meggsâ€™ fatherâ€™s testimony before 
  the jury to the fact that he heard the victimsâ€™ motherâ€™s voice on the telephone 
  two times during the same time period that the victims allege the abuse occurred.Â Â Â  

Meggs testified at trial that he had a sexual relationship with the victimsâ€™ 
  mother at the time of the allegations and that he spent the night at her house.Â  
  Meggs stated that when he learned of the victimsâ€™ allegations, he went to the 
  motherâ€™s house to find out more information.Â  When asked if the victimsâ€™ mother 
  discussed the allegations with him, Meggs stated that the only thing the mother 
  wanted to discuss was money, and she told Meggs she needed money.Â  Although 
  the court sustained the Stateâ€™s hearsay objection to this testimony, the State 
  did not move to strike and the jury was not instructed to disregard it.Â  Meggs 
  went on to testify that he provided between $2,000 and $3,000 in financial support 
  to the victimsâ€™ mother for bills and groceries. 
Although Meggs argues his fatherâ€™s excluded statements 
  were not hearsay because they were asserted to show a relationship between Meggs 
  and the victimsâ€™ mother, the record does not reflect that he advanced that reason 
  for admission at trial.Â  See State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 
  646, 576 S.E.2d 168, 174 (2003) (holding that an argument not raised before 
  the trial court was not preserved for appellate review).Â  Moreover, we find 
  that even assuming the statements were improperly excluded, it constituted harmless 
  error.Â  The improper exclusion of evidence is harmless where the evidence is 
  merely cumulative to other evidence properly admitted.Â  State v. Ferguson, 
  300 S.C. 408, 411, 388 S.E.2d 642, 644 (1990) (finding the trial judgeâ€™s refusal 
  to admit a statement was harmless error where it was cumulative to other testimony).Â  
  Meggs testified he had a relationship with the victimsâ€™ mother and that he spent 
  the night at her house.Â  Thus, exclusion of the fatherâ€™s testimony was not error 
  under the particular facts of this case.
B.
Meggs also asserts the trial court erred in excluding 
  his fatherâ€™s testimony and his testimony regarding the motherâ€™s demand for money 
  because it showed the victimsâ€™ mother made a prior inconsistent statement and 
  had a motive to encourage her children to lie.Â  Although the victimsâ€™ mother 
  denied having a relationship with Meggs and ever receiving money from him, Meggs 
  testified he gave her money and that it was not in the form of a loan.Â  Thus, 
  evidence was admitted that Meggs provided money to the victimsâ€™ mother.Â  Further, 
  the evidence of Meggsâ€™ guilt was overwhelming.Â  Several eyewitnesses testified 
  regarding the acts the victims were required to perform.Â  Other witnesses testified 
  that the boys told them of the acts and the stories were consistent.Â  Additionally, 
  as argued by the State, Meggs never laid a proper foundation under Rule 613(b), 
  SCRE, for admission of the fatherâ€™s testimony because the victimsâ€™ mother was 
  never given details of the statement or the opportunity to admit or deny the 
  statement. [3] Â  Finally, Meggsâ€™ 
  credibility was suspect as he admitted lying regarding his service in the National 
  Guard and in his credentials.Â  
The excluded testimony was cumulative to other 
  testimony in the record, and, in light of the overwhelming evidence of guilt, 
  it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.Â  Accordingly, 
  the decision of the trial court to exclude the testimony is affirmed.
CONCLUSION
The evidence supporting Meggsâ€™ guilt was overwhelming.Â  Thus, any error in 
  excluding Meggsâ€™ and his fatherâ€™s testimony regarding the victimsâ€™ mother was 
  harmless.Â  Because Meggs did not renew his objection to D.C.â€™s testimony at 
  the time it was offered, Meggs failed to preserve the prior bad act issue for 
  appeal.Â  Accordingly, Meggsâ€™ convictions and sentences are 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.


 
   
    [1] Â  Because oral argument would not assist the court in deciding this 
    case, we decide it without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â  

 
   
    [2] Â  Due to the sensitive nature of this case, we assign alternate initials 
    to protect the minor victims.Â  

 
   [3] Â  Rule 613(b), SCRE, provides 
    as follows:


  Extrinsic evidence of a prior inconsistent statement by a witness 
    is not admissible unless the witness is advised of the substance of the statement, 
    the time and place it was allegedly made, and the person to whom it was made, 
    and is given the opportunity to explain or deny the statement.Â  If a witness 
    does not admit that he has made the prior inconsistent statement, extrinsic 
    evidence of such statement is admissible.Â Â
